title.narrative: IMS Safeguarding media in transitional Afghanistan 2017-2022
IMS Säkerställa media genom Afghanistans transition, 2017-2022

description.narrative:
Organisationen har inkommit med en ansökan "Safeguarding media in transitional Afghanistan, Programme Proposal 2017-2020".
Det fortsatta programstödet i Afghanistan 2017-2020 har framtagits efter en konsultativ process med lokala partner runt om i landet, samt med andra relevanta målgrupper. Programmet bygger på de tidigare faserna av stödet (2008-2016). Syftet med stödet och dess yttersta målsättning är att bidra till trovärdig journalistik som kan förse medborgarna i Afghanistan med rättvisande och relevant information. Programmet står på två ben, ett där man verkar för att reducera risker som mediearbetare (journalister, media hur etc.) utsätts för i syfte att de alltjämt skall kunna verka inom sin profession. Det andra benet i programupplägget handlar om att bidra till trovärdig media rapportering som tar hänsyn till dels konfliktkänslighet dels är gendersensitiv. Vad den senare punkten syftar till är säkerställa att kvinnliga journalister får utbildning att verka för att bredda journalistiken i landet så att kvinnors möjlighet att beskriva konflikter utifrån ett jämställdhetsperspektiv, samt att kunna bibringa medborgarna relevanta nyheter genomlysta av kvinnors möjlighet till analys av olika samhällsproblem etc. Sidas övergripande bedömning av organisationen är att de är högst professionella och kompetenta med kapacitet att leverera resultat som planeras för.
Det ökande våldet och brist på säkerhet i Afghanistan drabbar särskilt hårt journalister vilket riskerar att begränsa yttrandefriheten i landet. Mediesektorn som generellt har vuxit snabbt sedan Taliban regimens fall 2001 har utgjort en av de stora landvinningarna i landet, men riskerar nu att falla tillbaka i termer av oberoende och som en viktig garant för demokratiutvecklingen i landet om inte journalister ges det stöd som krävs. Säkerheten för journalister har väsentligt försämrats de senast åren och 2016 var det värsta året sedan 2001, då totalt 13 journalister dödades och otaliga fler hotades och skadades. Situationen för kvinnliga journalister är värre än för män och där de möter många additionella hinder i sin verksamhetsutövning.
Verksamheten är högst relevant givet den nu existerande resultatstrategin för Afghanistan 2014-2019 som talar om behovet av att verka för ett starkt oberoende civilt samhälle som en viktig garant för ett fortsatt demokratiskt och fredlig utveckling i landet. I detta kan mediefrihet, nät och yttrandefrihet samt social medier i syfte att öka medborgarnas och civilsamhällets möjligheter till insyn och granskning utgöra en grundbult, och är inom den sfär organisationen verkar inom.
Sidas beslut föreslår att stöd ges till programmet "Safeguarding media in transitional Afghanistan 2017-2020" med ett maximalt belopp om MSEK 30.5, varav SEK 500 000 avsätts för en planerad mid-term review/översyn under 2018/2019.

The programme ”Safeguarding Media in Transitional Afghanistan” 2017-2020 has the ultimate aim to contribute to credible journalism that can provide the citizens of Afghanistan with accurate and relevant information. The contribution has two components, one being to secure safety for journalist including conflict sensitivity training, and 24/7 safety mechanism, the other being a focus on supporting/training female journalists for them to be able to work, and to cover news from a female perspective.

Question: There is a clear description of the interventions intended outcome. Answer: Yes. There is a clear description of the interventions intended outcome.
Question: There are objectives at different levels that together describe the intervention logic, i.e. how outputs will lead to the intended outcome. Answer: Yes. Question: There are relevant indicators with target values. Answer: Yes. There are relevant indicators with target values.
Question: There are baseline values to measure indicators against. Answer: Yes. There are baseline values to measure indicators against.
Question: Your partners results framework identifies critical assumptions for the achievement of the objectives. Answer: Yes. The partners results framework identifies critical assumptions for the achievement of the objectives.
Question: There is a sufficient approach to sustain intended outcomes over time? Answer: Yes. There is a sufficient approach to sustain intended outcomes over time. The environment in which media and journalists operate in Afghanistan makes it practically challenging to sustain results. It is an eternal strive to act and keep yourself relevant and marketable. After the fall of the Taliban movement in 2001 the media sector rose with striking pace. Many media houses and newspapers etc. saw the day of life. However, over time and also to some extent related to less interest of media support from development partners, and with a worsened security situation and economic downturn (accentuated after the withdrawal of ISAF forces in 2014) this has had negative impact on the sector as a whole. In a highly competitive market it is difficult to find common ground for the media industry's own investment in the self-regulatory system or in institutions for training and further training of journalists.
IMS/AJSC will continue advocating vis-a-vis relevant decision makers and relevant stakeholders in Afghanistan with the aim of pushing them to enhance their commitments to ensuring the safety of media workers. IMS will seek to consolidate relations and alliances established during the previous programme periods and push for concrete follow-up on pledges. Moreover, they will seek to strengthen existing relations and alliances with special attention to provincial decision makers and relevant partners in the field, such as provincial governors, religious leaders and media owners. One important point of departure for advocacy work efforts will be the UN Plan of Action on the Safety of Media workers and the Issue of Impunity, which provides a platform for engagement between governments and the international Community. UNESCO is involved in this process and will gain support by IMS/AJSC. The programme will seek to enhance and consolidate the institutional capacity of AJSC - both at HQ in Kabul but more so in the eight provinces plus 26 other provinces where they are active. IMS aims to delegate responsibilities from Copenhagen to Kabul HQ (AJSC) and having IMS/Copenhagen in charge of enhancing fundraising and in an advisory role.
IMS views on the programme sustainability approach is clearly reflected in the programme document; and which is to be based on the already existing national safety committee. AJSC, which is currently working very efficiently on Training of Trainers (ToT) training set up with local trainers. In this fashion the programme seeks to generate an increasingly sustainable, institutionalise and locally anchored safety committee with improved regional structures. By the end of the programme period it is envisaged that the safety committee will have enhanced its local sources of funding and gained a strong local capacity to continue its activities. Aim is here reaching this stage around 2020.
Question: There is an effort to ensure local ownership in the intervention set-up. Answer: Yes. There is an effort to ensure local ownership in the intervention set-up. IMS partnership is based on local ownership and priorities (see above). The way IMS emphasise on local ownership in their partnership with local actors is one of their major strengths. IMS is highly appreciated by the partners for this, which is easily verified in Kabul, and for the equality in the partnerships. One important facet or aspect to this is based on building mutual trust and confidence over a long time period. This is clearly the case in Afghanistan and where the media expert IMS has provided has been active here since the inception of the programme start i.e. late 2007. It is Sida's assessment that there are strong efforts to ensure local ownership in the programme.
Question: The intervention is supported by relevant stakeholders. Answer: Yes. The intervention is supported by relevant stakeholders. The end-of-period points out that IMS' close and continuous engagement with all relevant stakeholders around media (journalist safety, legislation and policies driven) is the explanation to why the programme has been successful in contributing to positive change. IMS' contribution is deemed highly valuable and the way they work and liaise with local partners (civil society and government, media houses etc.) has been appreciated. The safety mechanism set up in 2011 has meant focussing and strengthening the exposed role of journalists; females and males, and in a situation where the security for the profession has gone bad the necessity to assist and reduce risks for journalist as a group has gone up substantively.
Question: Please provide additional comments and/or motivations to the questions above. Answer: IMS/AJSC has provided a programme based on a theory of change that Sida assesses to be comprehensive and logical. IMS/AJSC has also developed an overall results matrix for the proposed programme, which is ambitious and comprehensive. The LFA is not broken down year by year but is focussing on end results towards the year 2020. The LFA is in no way quantitative but rather more complex with only qualitative indicators which make it more challenging to follow yet more interesting and relevant. There is set baselines for the different outcomes and outputs which is appreciated.
Previous viewpoints and some external Reviews of IMS has indicated weaker results frameworks. As many other development partners IMS and AJSC have struggled with establishing indicators that are measurable, and at the same time actually depicting the desired changes that a programme is attempting to achieve, as well as in aggregating data at higher levels.
With a view to address these weaknesses and follow recommendations from earlier phases of the programme implemented in Afghanistan, IMS/AJSC claims that they have laid down a lot of work in finalising the results framework and which Sida understands have been done in an interactive and inclusive way between IMS and AJSC. The Afghanistan LFA and matrix is building on recent experiences gained by IMS in developing their large scale MENA programme and which currently Sida is funding in the region covering a number of countries. Thought the MENA programme is a lot vaster and more complex the Afghanistan framework is building on this very few features and lessons learnt from that process. Sida appreciate the work laid down and can see that IMS in its Afghanistan programme has further developed its programmatic thinking and which is clearly indicated by the theory of change and its adjoining results framework. It should be reasonable to give IMS/AJSC time to develop a monitoring framework in line with the commitments made in the programmatic proposal. Sida has proposed (see budgetary section) to allocate money, part of the total budget envelop, in order for having a Mid-Term Evaluation done of the programme in late 2018/early 2019. Since no any external evaluation has ever be done in Afghanistan the time is ripe for such an undertaking. IMS has agreed to this and do also see a need and the benefit to have it done. If a Mid-Term is conducted then that one could either confirm that the results framework produced holds in grounds, and such it not then there would still be time for IMS/AJSC to take corrective measures and addressing potential shortcomings during the remaining two years of operations. Annual plans and budgets will of course be a condition in the agreement.
Question: Resultat och måluppfyllelse: Utvecklingsinsatsen har mål som möjliggör uppföljning och rapportering av resultat, en rimlig budget i förhållande till mål och förväntade resultat, samt förutsättningar att bidra till att effektmål (outcome) uppnås. Answer: Yes. Resultat och måluppfyllelse: Utvecklingsinsatsen har mål som möjliggör uppföljning och rapportering av resultat, en rimlig budget i förhållande till mål och förväntade resultat, samt förutsättningar att bidra till att effektmål (outcome) uppnås. IMS har lämnat ett ambitiöst förslag som innefattar en långsiktig fyraårig programstrategi. De har byggt upp sin föreslagna verksamhet i nära samklang med sin lokala partners organisation AJSC och bygger på en förändringsteori som Sida bedömer som logisk och genomförbar. Självklart är dock det man föresatt sig att göra problematisk givet den komplexa miljö som programmet kommer att genomföras i. Risker som finns angivna av IMS själva klargör med önskvärd tydlighet att de är väl medvetna om att detta är ett högrisk program men inte desto mindre högst relevant och behövligt. Sida kommer följa upp insatsen på övergripande nivå och har som välkänt begränsningar i hur följa upp programmet på marken i Afghanistan. Sida (ambassaden i Kabul) gör, om så bedöms möjligt, fältturer i landet och att man då söker kontakt med IMS provinsiella koordinatörer (finns åtta stycken) och/eller andra IMS/AJSC medarbetare i landet.
Programmet är väl utformat och bygger på de tidigare programfaser som IMS/AJSC genomfört i Afghanistan sedan nästa tio år tillbaka i tid. LFA:n som redovisats bygger på ett fördjupat grundarbete som bedrivits i samklang med Sida/MENA då IMS:s MENA program framtagits. I och med detta har IMS förstärkt och förbättrad sitt tänkande och förmåga att definiera sitt program utifrån ett mer avancerat LFA tänk. Nuvarande resultatramverk har de facto baselines (baslinjer, grundvärden definierade), till detta kommer indikatorer angivna såväl på output som outcome nivåer. Dock kan konstateras att merparten av indikatorer som IMS angivit är kvalitativa och ytterst få kvantitativa. Samtidigt som detta gör uppföljningen av stödet svårare att bedöma gör det samtidigt att satta nivåer/ambitionsvärden mer relevanta. Utan tvekan lär den komplexa miljön och svårigheter kring att i slutändan "mäta" eller bedöma resultat innebära utmaningar för såväl IMS att redovisa mot detta resultatramverk och för såväl Sida som för IMS/AJSC att tolka resultat (på mikro/meso och makro nivåer). Att tolka aggregerade resultat, speciellt i termer av årliga resultat syftande till att nå slutmålet år 2020 kan kräva vidare analyser. Det är därför än viktigare, bedömer Sida, att föranstalta en översyn/utvärdering i mitten av programperioden för att dels då se var i processen man nått, och om det skulle vissa sig att problem uppstått kunna förslå mått och steg att söka korrigera ansatsen. Ytterst kommer självfallet de långsiktiga effektmålens resultat att bero på hur utvecklingen i landet kommer fortgå.
Question: Hållbarhet: De effekter utvecklingsinsatsen avser att leda till har förutsättningar att vara uthålliga. Answer: Yes. Hållbarhet: De effekter utvecklingsinsatsen avser att leda till har förutsättningar att vara uthålliga. IMS arbetar med en holistisk ansats för medieutveckling som bygger på att skapa olika partnersamarbeten och att då lägga stor vikt på lokalt ägarskap. IMS kommer att verka för att få lokala organisationer att få bättre möjligheter, att över tid utveckla deras kompetens och kunnande långsiktigt. De försöker även, tydligt markerat i Afghanistan att verka för i detta fall AJSC möjligheter att bli en egen självständig organisation. Glädjande nog har också AJSC fr. o. m. 1 januari 2017 registrerats som en egen organisation och kommer i detta framtida programstöd utgöra avtalspart med IMS.
IMS lägger generellt stort fokus på att stärka säkerhetsaspekter hos sina samarbetspartner hos mediekåren och hos enskilda journalister över hela landet. På så vis försöker man bygga kapacitet som kan bestå och förhoppningsvis bli bärkraftigt då IMS ej längre kan eller förmår verka i landet. IMS ser stor vikt i att stödja organisationer bli självständiga och självförsörjande. Sidas bedömning är att IMS bidrar till att öka förutsättningarna för att denna utvecklingsinsats blir uthållig.
Question: Summarise the intervention logic Answer: The two outcomes assumed to contribute to the desired long-term impact (credible media continues to provide Afghan public with reliable and relevant information) are 1. risks faced by media workers are mitigated and 2. credible media report in a conflict- and gender-sensitive manner. The theory of change underpinning the relation between the impact and the first outcome is that safety and protection for media workers is an indispensable and primary precondition for securing the continued flow of accurate, credible and relevant media output. The theory of change for the relation between the impact and the second outcome is that conflict and gender sensitive reporting is a vital means to providing accurate and relevant information while avoiding to fan the flames of the conflict, and to ensuring that media outputs cater to the needs and interests of the broadest possible range of segments of society, not only traditional power-holders. In addition, conflict-sensitive reporting increases the safety of the individual media worker. In order to facilitate monitoring of the program, four tangible bridging objectives have been formulated: i) Strengthened safety mechanism operates effectively; ii) The framework for professional reporting in conflict is ensured; iii) Voice of women through media is not lost, and; iv) Media workers from credible media trained by AJSC apply conflict- and gender-sensitive reporting skills.

description.narrative:
The Narrative, financial, and audit report for 1 January - 31 December 2020 are now approved and assessed to be good enough to be approved. The approval process has however been complicated since the financial report and audit report did not fulfill the basic requirements which are stipulated in the agreement between Sida and IMS. Please read more about it here in under under the Financial and Audit report.
Find below the most relevant information in the reports and comments on the process of information sharing between IMS and Sida regarding the activities performed within the project in 2020.
Narrative report
The report is in line with the work plan. It presents an overview of the results achieved in relation to the objectives. The narrative report also presents lessons-learned.
2020 was a challenging year for the programme with the Covid-19 crisis, the fragile political situation in the country, increasing insecurity and fear among journalists and media workers. The direct attacks and assassinations of journalists created fear amongst the media workers and had a direct impact of the reporting by journalist, often resulting in self censorship and impact on what to report about and were. The economic impact of the Covid-19 crisis also resulted in challenges for the private owned media outlets to finance their activities. A lot of journalists lost their jobs during 2020 due to the financial crisis. Other female journalists (300) lost their jobs because of security reasons. This has of course affected the capacity to generate content.
The program has during 2020 continued to work with relocation of journalists to save lives and to give training, legal and financial assistance and continuing the advocacy work to make sure that the freedom of expression is still on the government's and donors' agenda. Data for 2020 shows that there was a 26 percent of increase in level of violence and threats against media and journalists during 2020 compared to 2019. The program recorded threats and violence against 132 journalists and media workers. 7 journalists were killed during 2020 in Afghanistan. Some journalists were relocated to other parts of the country and some have left the country to India, Turkey or Uzbekistan.
Activities that include direct physical interaction were limited and post phoned, around 20 percent less than planned. The pandamic had serious impact in the whole country. The programme managed to provide more phsycosocial counselling for traumatized journalists and assist with medical treatment. IMS and AJSC prepared the road map for freedom of expression and the press freedom document together with the Afghan media representatives to preserve and uphold the press freedom and freedom of expression as fundamental principles during the peace talks in Doha. Work was also done to to strengthen AJSC even more in order to prepare for a direct support to AJSC from Sida in 2022 and onwards.
According to the report, out of the program's 11 outputs, the programme is on trac or ahead of schedule with 6. The programme is on trac for the other 5 outputs.
The dialogue before approving the narrative report has been about the roles of AJSC and IMS and who is doing what. in the final approved report this has been clarified by a foot note on page 28. Since the situation in Afghanistan has dramaticly changed since 15 of August when the Taliban took controle over Kabul focus has been on how to continue and adapt the progam activities and the activity period beyond 2021.
